Package org.reactivestreams.utils

Reactive streams support.

This provides utilities for building stream graphs that consume or produce elements using the Flow.Publisher, Flow.Subscriber and Flow.Processor interfaces.

There are four primary classes used for building these graphs:

  • PublisherBuilder, which when built produces a Flow.Publisher
  • SubscriberBuilder, which when built produces a SubscriberWithResult
  • ProcessorBuilder, which when built produces a Flow.Processor
  • CompletionBuilder, which when built produces a CompletionStage

Operations on these builders may change the shape of the builder, for example, ProcessorBuilder.toList() changes the builder to a SubscriberBuilder, since the processor now has a termination stage to direct its elements to.

SubscriberBuilder's are a special case, in that they don't just build a Flow.Subscriber, they build a SubscriberWithResult, which encapsulates both a Flow.Subscriber and a CompletionStage of the result of the subscriber processing. This CompletionStage will be redeemed with a result when the stream terminates normally, or if the stream terminates with an error, will be redeemed with an error. The result is specific to whatever the Flow.Subscriber does, for example, in the case of ProcessorBuilder.toList(), the result will be a List of all the elements produced by the Flow.Processor, while in the case of ProcessorBuilder.findFirst(), it's an Optional of the first element of the stream. In some cases, there is no result, in which case the result is the Void type, and the CompletionStage is only useful for signalling normal or error termination of the stream.

The CompletionBuilder builds a closed graph, in that case both a Flow.Publisher and Flow.Subscriber have been provided, and building the graph will run it and return the result of the Flow.Subscriber as a CompletionStage.

An example use of this API is perhaps you have a Flow.Publisher of rows from a database, and you want to output it as a comma separated list of lines to publish to an HTTP client request body, which expects a Flow.Publisher of ByteBuffer. Here's how this might be implemented: 

   Publisher<Row> rowsPublisher = ...;

   Publisher<ByteBuffer> bodyPublisher =
     // Create a publisher builder from the rows publisher
     ReactiveStreams.fromPublisher(rowsPublisher)
       // Map the rows to CSV strings
       .map(row ->
         String.format("%s, %s, %d\n", row.getString("firstName"),
           row.getString("lastName"), row.getInt("age))
       )
       // Convert to ByteBuffer
       .map(line -> ByteBuffer.wrap(line.getBytes("utf-8")))
       // Build the publisher
       .build();

   // Make the request
   HttpClient client = HttpClient.newHttpClient();
   client.send(
     HttpRequest
       .newBuilder(new URI("http://www.foo.com/"))
       .POST(BodyProcessor.fromPublisher(bodyPublisher))
       .build()
   );
  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ReactiveStreamsEngine
    An engine for turning reactive streams graphs into Flow publishers/subscribers.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CompletionBuilder<T>
    A builder for a closed reactive streams graph.
    ProcessorBuilder<T,R>
    A builder for a Flow.Processor.
    PublisherBuilder<T>
    A builder for a Flow.Publisher.
    ReactiveStreams
    Primary entry point into the Reactive Streams utility API.
    ReactiveStreamsBuilder<S>
    Superclass of all reactive streams builders.
    SubscriberBuilder<T,R>
    A builder for a Flow.Subscriber and its result.
    SubscriberWithResult<T,R>
    A subscriber with a result.
